problems.title: Shortest Common Supersequence Length
problems.description:
Problem Statement

Given two strings S1 and S2, find the length of the shortest string that has both S1 and S2 as subsequences.

This is called the Shortest Common Supersequence (SCS).

Key Insight: SCS length = len(S1) + len(S2) - LCS(S1, S2).

The LCS appears only once in the supersequence, while non-LCS characters from both strings are added.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
geek
eke

Sample Output
5

Explanation:
S1 = "geek", S2 = "eke"
LCS = "ek" (length 2)

SCS length = 4 + 3 - 2 = 5
One possible SCS is "geeke".
problems.constraints:
1 <= |S1|, |S2| <= 1000
Strings contain only lowercase English letters.

if __name__ == '__main__':
    import sys
    data = sys.stdin.read().strip().split('\n')
    s1 = data[0]
    s2 = data[1]
    sol = Solution()
    print(sol.shortestCommonSupersequence(s1, s2))

hintsList: First compute the LCS of the two strings using the standard LCS DP algorithm.
SCS length = |S1| + |S2| - LCS_length. The LCS characters are shared, so we don't count them twice.
